ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara Brock was the only teaching assistant
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara Brock

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  She gave great comments on our assignments, was available for general questions, and contributed to the in class experience.

Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Because of the style of the course, the teaching assistant participated in discussion alongside the class and offered some illuminating points. She also provided useful comments to the weekly response papers.
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara was a really helpful sounding board for paper ideas and great at clarifying and condensing lines of discussion in class.
Instructor: Samara Meade Brock  Samara was wonderful. She offered thoughtful comments during discussion and helpful feedback on writing assignments.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Best class I have ever taken anywhere in my life. It was a game changer. Open discussions pushed us to think and reflect about issues that build on current themes.
This was the best FES course I took this semester

Professor Hebert's class was a defining experience for most if not all of the students enrolled in it. The course readings and discussions changed how I view the global economic system and how humans interact with one another. F&ES should offer more courses like Producing and Consuming Nature.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Thinking and analyzing and understanding classic authors in a whole new light.
Format was great. One of my favorite classes of all time. Really got me to think critically in new ways.

Syllabus selection was very good, also happened to have a great cohort which stimulated engaging, thoughtful discussion. Prof. Hebert's guiding hand was deft, pivoting or recapitulating the conversation when necessary but letting student voices take precedent.
Great readings, good space for and class size for in depth discussions.

Really interesting look into a lot of trends that are carrying more and more weight within the environmental movement. I took the class because I was interested in its theoretical questions, but it also ended up providing a very practical and pragmatic grounding for understanding the interface between economic and environmental issues.
The readings, reading responses, and discussions were all terrific. The other students were all very engaged with the course material.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: None, it was great.
The required reading is rather high. An extra day to complete weekly assignments would have been appreciated.

Not sure if this is really a suggestion for the course, but greater access to visual aids of some kind (apart from the whiteboard) might be helpful, especially for student presenters synthesizing the readings.
The readings in the final weeks were not as interesting to me as the readings in the first half of the course.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Great
Not too much lecture as this course was a seminar-style

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course has taught me to go deeper into reasons behind actions, and provided a framework for thought that is not being teached elsewhere in FES.
Originally seemed like just a personal interest, but in the end proved a great integrated framework through which to conceive of my larger academic experience. I found it to be incredibly valuable
Please see answer to question 17.
This course will help me frame my research questions regarding the political economies of agroforestry commodities.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest in the readings, and for a change from my typically quantitative coursework
Interesting syllabus, wanted an introduction to current and classic scholars in anthropology and related disciplines

The course description and readings seemed - and were - really interesting, and different from the kinds of analysis my other classes at FES have offered. I thought that approaching the field I'm interested in from a new perspective would help me build a new framework for understanding how to both critique and build more effective types of projects.
I liked the reading list and wanted a course that would expand my understanding of anthropological issues surrounding agricultural commodities.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Far exceeded them. I dedicated twice the amount of time for this course but got twice the satisfaction.
Yes
Yes, I feel much more confident in my ability to discuss Marx, Polanyi, Bourdeiu and contemporary authors like James Scott, Timothy Mitchell, and (recently deceased) Coronil
Critical thinking/reading skills as well as others
Yes; the readings and discussions provided a lot of information and insight into a new field, within a very limited window of time.
Yes. In fact, the course exceeded my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I worked with one student to co-lead the discussion one week. I believe we worked well together
Bit hard to juggle leading a discussion between two people, as the conversation inevitably seemed to shift to cut off the introduction one person had planned for later.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be sure to take it. Make sure you have sufficient time in your weeks to devote 2 full days to reading.

Start readings early in the week, put some effort into your weekly responses because Prof. Hebert and the TA give useful, substantive feedback each week and because it will help you organize your thoughts for the weekly discussion
Really worthwhile class, that offers a valuable framework for understanding a lot of key environmental debates. Just be sure you are prepared to devote a large amount of time to the readings!
Be prepared to do a lot of heavy reading and thinking.
